column1: Social networks can tell us something about the people in them. When somebody is in a difficult situation
column2: they can use a little help from their friends. Who has the most friends in Frozen? That is difficult to tell just from watching the movie
column3: but we can study another kind of social network—the network of who talks to whom. This network is not exactly the same as a friendship network
column4: but it is much easier to accurately determine who talks to whom in the movie than it is to decide exactly who is friends with each other and how strong those friendships are. In this network of conversations
column6: so we will suppose that she has nine friends. Mathematicians say that Anna is a node in this network
column7: that she has a degree of nine
column8: and that those nine friends are her neighbors. Similarly
column9: Elsa has a degree of eight
column10: because she has eight friends; and Kristoff has a degree of six. Calculating somebody's degree is one way to measure their importance
column11: but there are also many other ways.
